review.title: Using Qualitative Relationships for Bounding Probability Distributions
review.abstract: We exploit qualitative probabilistic relationships among variables for computing bounds of conditional probability distributions of interest in Bayesian networks. Using the signs of qualitative relationships, we can implement abstraction operations that are guaranteed to bound the distributions of interest in the desired direction. By evaluating incrementally improved approximate networks, our algorithm obtains monotonically tightening bounds that converge to exact distributions. For supermodular utility functions, the tightening bounds monotonically reduce the set of admissible decision alternatives as well.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Fourteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1998)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Fourteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1998)

There is a school of research that works on modeling uncertain situations using proba­ bility intervals or other alternatives, and they also study al­ gorithms for computing probability intervals (Walley 1991; Thone, Gtintzer, & KieBling 1992; Chrisman 1996; Luo et al. 1996; Cozman 1997).

metadata.abstractText: We exploit qualitative probabilistic relationships among variables for computing bounds of con­ ditional probability distributions of interest in Bayesian networks. Using the signs of qualita­ tive relationships, we can implement abstraction operations that are guaranteed to bound the dis­ tributions of interest in the desired direction. By evaluating incrementally improved approximate networks, our algorithm obtains monotonically tightening bounds that converge to exact distri­ butions. For supermodular utility functions, the tightening bounds monotonically reduce the set of admissible decision alternatives as well.
